Treatment: IBS management includes dietary changes such as a low FODMAP diet, increasing fiber for constipation-predominant IBS, and avoiding trigger foods. Stress reduction techniques like mindfulness or cognitive-behavioral therapy can help. Medications may include antispasmodics or drugs targeting bowel movement regulation.

Drugs.Name: Duspatalin
Drugs.Description: Antispasmodic for relieving bowel cramps.

Drugs.Name: Enterogermina
Drugs.Description: Probiotic to support gut flora.

Drugs.Name: Colpermin
Drugs.Description: Peppermint oil capsule for IBS symptoms.

Treatment: Treatment includes weight management, physical therapy, and assistive devices. Pain is managed with analgesics and topical or oral anti-inflammatories. In advanced cases, intra-articular injections or joint replacement surgery may be required.

Drugs.Name: Voltaren Emulgel
Drugs.Description: Topical NSAID for joint pain.

Drugs.Name: Dolgit
Drugs.Description: Anti-inflammatory cream for musculoskeletal pain.

Drugs.Name: Move Free
Drugs.Description: Supplement for joint health support.

Treatment: Acute attacks are managed with triptans, NSAIDs, and anti-nausea medications. Preventive treatments include beta blockers, anticonvulsants, and CGRP inhibitors. Lifestyle changes such as regular sleep and avoiding triggers are crucial.

Drugs.Name: Zomig
Drugs.Description: Used to relieve acute migraine attacks.

Drugs.Name: Avmigran
Drugs.Description: Combination treatment for migraine relief.

Drugs.Name: Migraleve
Drugs.Description: Migraine-specific analgesic with anti-nausea component.

Treatment: Treatment depends on the cause: viral forms are self-limiting and require only supportive care, bacterial conjunctivitis is treated with antibiotic eye drops, and allergic types benefit from antihistamines and avoiding allergens.

Drugs.Name: Tobrased
Drugs.Description: Antibiotic eye drops for bacterial infections.

Drugs.Name: Allergo-Comod
Drugs.Description: Eye drops for allergic conjunctivitis.

Drugs.Name: Refresh Tears
Drugs.Description: Lubricating drops for symptom relief.

Treatment: Eradication of Helicobacter pylori using combination antibiotic therapy is the main approach. Proton pump inhibitors are used for acid suppression. Lifestyle modifications include avoiding NSAIDs, alcohol, and spicy foods.

Drugs.Name: Nolpaza
Drugs.Description: Proton pump inhibitor for ulcer healing.

Drugs.Name: Flagyl
Drugs.Description: Used in H. pylori eradication regimens.

Drugs.Name: Ulcuran
Drugs.Description: H2 receptor blocker for acid control.

Treatment: First-line therapy includes alpha-blockers and 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors to relax prostate muscles and reduce its size. Minimally invasive procedures or surgery (TURP) may be necessary for severe symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Xatral
Drugs.Description: Alpha-blocker that relaxes bladder neck muscles.

Drugs.Name: Proscar
Drugs.Description: Reduces prostate size and improves symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Uroxatral
Drugs.Description: Used to treat urinary problems in men.

Treatment: Saline nasal irrigation and decongestants are first-line. Antibiotics are reserved for bacterial infections. Chronic sinusitis may require corticosteroid sprays or surgical intervention such as functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).

Drugs.Name: Nasonex
Drugs.Description: Corticosteroid spray to reduce nasal inflammation.

Drugs.Name: Rhinocort
Drugs.Description: Nasal spray for allergy-related sinus symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Augmentin
Drugs.Description: Antibiotic used in bacterial sinusitis.

Treatment: Uncomplicated UTIs are usually treated with a short course of oral antibiotics. Drinking plenty of fluids helps flush out bacteria. For recurrent cases, longer treatments or prophylactic antibiotics may be used.

Drugs.Name: Monurol
Drugs.Description: Single-dose treatment for uncomplicated UTI.

Drugs.Name: Urocare
Drugs.Description: Urinary antiseptic for infection control.

Drugs.Name: Hiprex
Drugs.Description: Used for prevention of recurrent UTIs.

Treatment: Medicated shampoos containing antifungals or corticosteroids are the main treatment. In facial or body involvement, topical antifungal creams are used. Maintenance therapy helps prevent relapse.

Drugs.Name: Ketoral
Drugs.Description: Antifungal shampoo to reduce scalp inflammation.

Drugs.Name: Sebiprox
Drugs.Description: Medicated shampoo for seborrheic dermatitis.

Drugs.Name: Travocort
Drugs.Description: Combination cream with antifungal and anti-inflammatory action.

Treatment: Asymptomatic gallstones may not need treatment. Symptomatic cases are typically treated with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Non-surgical patients may use bile acid medications to dissolve stones, but recurrence is common.

Drugs.Name: Ursofalk
Drugs.Description: Used to dissolve certain types of gallstones.

Drugs.Name: Buscopan
Drugs.Description: Relieves abdominal cramps and colicky pain.

Drugs.Name: Debridat
Drugs.Description: Improves bile flow and digestive symptoms.
